review_title: I was worried about staffing ratios
pros: I really enjoyed the onboarding process with Pres Homes. They provided ample opportunities for gaining the right experience and skills for working among the residents.
cons: I felt like I experienced a bait and switch when it came to working with Pres Homes. On which, I truly did believe that I was going to be able to provide good care for the residents ensuring that they could thrive. Although, my first day of orientation I realized that that was going to be difficult noticing the dynamics between staff and the low ratios of staff and resident. I didn't feel like it was fair for me to be paid less providing direct care to patients than I would be answering emails. I feel for the residents, their families, and their staff for the current conditions of pay, ratios, and ability for additional career opportunities.

I would say that many find how to use their God-given gifts in service to others in many different ways while working at PHS. The CEO is a dedicated servant leader who is widely trusted not only in our organization but within the state and national industry leaders.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Residents, Being able to pick when to come in if on call.
cons: No help, running around with head cut off, equipment breaking down, and sometimes never fixed, supervisors don’t give a crap about the job, but pretend to. The supervisors don’t get dinged ever for being late or leaving early when employees do, and they take vacations, or have “family emergencies” all the time, go home early and don’t actually supervise which causes most workers to eat or disappear. You’re stuck doing all the work. Supervisors don’t care to fix things when you complain. Using trays to clean tables rather than carts so it takes longer and hurts you back. Pay sucks. People who have more seniority can berate you, or sexually harass you, and not get into trouble. Coworkers gossip which feels like you’re back in high school. Point system is unfair. Both supervisors and employees should both be held accountable if they don’t do what they’re suppose to. Some residents play games who have a huge stick up their butt when trying to do your job. Stand up not needed because it takes up valuable time to get things set up before you serve. Not worth it!

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Roseville, MN
pros: The worst facility to work at!!!
cons: THEY DONT TREAT RESIDENTS RIGHT AT ALL, don’t sent your parents or family there

job_title: CNA in Spring Lake Park, MN
pros: They hired dependable & knowledgeable CNAs.
cons: Management was too into climbing the corporate ladder. Building manager was a drama queen, who was used to having her behind kissed by the staff; if you didn't play her game, she found a way to nit-pick and eventually force you out. She ran the place like a prison warden. If a resident with dementia showed up in the dining room in a robe, or worse, some slippers, the manager would "have a talk" with the resident. She treated them like children and was condescending. She hurt a lot of residents feelings. She was so into how the place "looked", and only cared about the residents who were not a problem.  The nurses hired were young & pretty & very interested in climbing the corporate ladder. They dressed up and wore their jewelry & open-toed heels. The last nurse- supervisor I had was so disrespectful to the CNA's , very  sarcastic & unprofessional. The meetings before starting the shift were dreadful: their hypocritical "Christian" beliefs were shoved down employees throats every day. I put up with this crap for 3 miserable years. I was so relieved and happy to get out of Presbyterian Homes.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Spring Park, MN
pros: Great residents. Always something going on. Something new to learn. Great food from the kitchen and incentives to pick up shifts.
cons: I worked there for four years. Every day I dealt with lazy coworkers being on their phones and ignoring resident needs. I spent four years cleaning up after everyone's incomplete work. Management never did anything about my coworkers attitudes or phone usage. Meanwhile I was always bright, cheery, and happy to pitch in and do everything. If I ever used my phone it was to check the time or time a pulse when I forgot my watch at home. Management was all over me the second I did that. Definite favouritism with employees, but always the lazy aides that were the favorites who could do no wrong.

pros: The residence are great, I enjoyed resolving or fixing any problems that they had on any given day. Enjoyed keeping and providing them the best service possible given the circumstances. Independent living, assisted living and dementia ward.
cons: Front office, never available if you had any issues to discuss concerning equipment. Upper management stance ?  repair existing equipment that was either not repairable or obsolete.  Snow blowers, vacuum cleaners, and even personnel ladders. Basically upper management didn't fund the maintenance department and refused to increase the submitted budget. Budget was based on number of green slips completed, so preventative maintenance suffered. Not that the employees of the maintenance department and supervisor didn't do everything possible to maintain the facility. Upper management would not listen.

review_title: Has really changed.  Not a nice place to work anymore
pros: The residents and families are the best
cons: The human resources person talks about everyone and always wants to write people up.  The nurses are always in their office all the time and never seem to remember what you tell them.  Then they blame us for them not remembering something.  They say they are a Christian place to work but it doesn't feel like it the way they treat people.

pros: It is a large organization and there is opportunity for growth within the company. Workers have the ability to transfer to sites as there are a lot in the metro area.
cons: They are a non profit organization but they try to cut costs. Nurses and CNAs hours get cut and they are really strict about time management. There are a lot of delegated tasks I feel are inappropriate. The residents are also inappropriately placed and require more help than appropriate for this setting. Nurses over look the care and status of them, but they rely on the aides to do most tasks a nurse would do with little training.

review_title: managers do not care - they lie
pros: Get to visit with people that remind me of my grandma and grandpa.  Made new friends from school who worked here to.
cons: I worked in the dining room as we were always short staffed. They do not hire enough workers and pay less than fast food. Even the grocery store pays more. Other managers said they would come help but they never do. They walk past us and do not even say hello or make eye contact like they are better then we are. They go to my boss and tell her we are goofing of when they are the ones gossiping and visiting with eachother in the hall when WE NEEDED HELP. But they can find time to go smoke.  Friends from school told me it is not a good job - wish i listened - DO NOT WORK HERE!!!!!

pros: I am a server at the Interlude Restorative Suites location. The starting pay is good for a teen at their first job, at $10 per hour. The coworkers are nice, and many of the residents are very nice.
cons: The job is very stressful. My first day of training was 9 hours long with only one other server for much of the time. There is a ton to learn, like where all the different food products are kept, how to take orders by phone for room service, how to enter it into the computers for the cook, how to deliver the food, what to do when there is no food to prepare... Since the culinary department is way too understaffed, I was thrown right into doing all of it.

review_title: Beautiful facilities, great ideals/practices, but below-average pay/benefits with above-average workplace stress.
job_title: TMA/Resident Assistant-Care Center in Saint Paul, MN
pros: In my opinion, the pros are somewhat limited.  Most of the facilities are beautifully designed and meant to appear high-end, and have a very comfortable home-like atmosphere for the residents versus the institutional feel a lot of senior living facilities have.  The company has a great mission statement (creating smiles in the eyes of our residents), values, motto, and a list of best practices that make it seem very resident-centered. An example of one of the practices is to accompany guests to their destination whenever possible instead of simply pointing out directions.  Another pro, I think,  would be the number of sites in the area, and how easy it is to transfer to a different location if you are moving or find a more appealing position within the company.  Pres Homes also encourages employees to seek out higher positions within the company, they seem to prefer to hire internally when upper level positions are available, such as a staff RN in the care center applying for a clinical administrator position at a different site, they really do promote upward mobility.
cons: There is far too much micro managing going on within the company.  A lot of corporate rules and standards that trickle down through various levels of management are often unrealistic in practice, and if you question these standards, or propose an idea to your direct supervisor you think might work better in a particular situation, you'll most likely never hear back.  The high-ups are very, very distant from the front line workers like myself, a nursing assistant.  They tend to go by industry standards for a lot of things such as the amount of staff per residents, and this is not always realistic once you factor in other things like how the nursing assistants at Pres Homes are expected to not only perform nursing assistant-specific duties, but also dietary, housekeeping, laundry, therapy programs, simple treatments, etc, and also they lavish, spacious layout of some facilities (all private rooms split into separate neighborhoods) gives one nursing assistant 3 times the square footage to cover compared to the traditional nursing homes that the "industry standards" are based off of.  The pay is below average, lower than MOST of the similar companies, due to the fact that the facilities themselves is where Pres puts the bulk of its money, not towards its employees.  The employees are expected to complete much more than they can realistically accomplish within their shift, they're CONSTANTLY short staffed (at least 3 days a week my shift is short 1 or 2 CNA's), you're persecuted if you clock out a minute late because you hadn't finished all of the extra work, the benefits are lackluster at best, your supervisors don't acknowledge your accomplishments because they're constantly stressed as well, and there has been a high turn over rate ever since I started 3 years ago.  And expect a phone call most of your days off from your scheduler asking if you'll pick up a shift, without a call-in bonus, and don't expect overtime, EVER.  People start working for Pres, see how stressful it is every day, and leave.  Happens every month.   Ive ben doing this type of work for 7 years and have worked for a few different companies in that time, none as all-around frustrating as Pres Homes.  I just feel like the high-up corporate folks don't know, and don't care what we go through, and only care about putting up their next building, and once its up, they move on to the next.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Residents were wonderful; some co-workers were as well
cons: Management was very dysfunctional - in short, they 'walk the talk' only with the residents of their facilities - as an employer, they are like any other mid-size corporation - all about money. Lots of corporate politics.

pros: Love working for a non-profit where all of the focus is on the residents and where I feel empowered as an employee to do the right thing and expect the same of others.  Faith-based culture also stands out - with real opportunities to share our own joys and concerns and to lift people up when they need support.  Very mission forward organization, and growing, so lots of opportunity. Beautiful and clean places to work and supportive culture with emphasis on growing people internally.
cons: The industry is certainly facing workforce shortages (who isn't?), but PHS has a much lower turnover rate than others.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
- Some residents are a pleasure to care for and appreciate the assistance
- Some coworkers are high-functioning and embody the values of the organization
cons:
- Management can feel a bit patronizing at times
- Workload is such that taking a break and leaving on time can be difficult
- Facility is occasionally understaffed

The unfortunate reality is that funds are chronically tight in institutional long-term care. Thus, staff at all levels tend to have heavy workloads and receive only modest pay.  If Presbyterian Homes and Services, as a non-profit corporation cannot make a decent "go" of long-term care, one questions the essence of this model of healthcare.

review_title: Mismanaged company that doesn't follow own mission statement
pros: This can be a fun a fun place to work at times, but this is only because of certain co-workers, and residents. The residents usually appreciate what you do for them, and can be enjoyable to work for. This company will give entry level people with no experience a chance in a field that otherwise repels the uninitiated. My supervisors were generally awesome!
cons: Silly rules regarding sick days and time off that are dysfunctional. Although my supervisory staff were mostly competent and good, they were powerless against the corporate office to make common sense decisions on broken policies. There is a corporate office that hands-down decisions that often don't seem to have relevance to the needs of the residents and direct care staff. Decisions are based on money more than providing a positive care experience, and the care staff are expected to pick up the slack, or else! Some policies seem to only have the purpose of punishing staff. They don't make money or increase service to residents. Staff are given residents with acute and constant needs, but aren't provided the time to meet these needs correctly. I have never worked for a company that has made decisions on staffing in such an irresponsible manner. Residents don't get routine cares. When it does become a problem it is always the fault of care staff. Even when it is obvious the real reason is a lack of allotted hours on the schedule. Even when simple care ratios show that there is no way you could complete their care plans on time. Pay is comparable to similar companies. Benefits are terrible. They don't pay much if at all on medical insurance, but you get their group policy. Honestly for just a few dollars more a month you could pick up your own policy, which may have slightly better coverage. Management is full of lip service and have no accountability. This trickles down until it lands on the shoulders of direct care staff who have to "fix" or "deal" with the resulting issues to get their jobs done, on top of their actual their duties. It is irritating how a non-profit will make decisions based on a bottom line instead of quality of care.

pros: Good experience, got to interact with some very nice residents, good starting pay
cons: The supervisors (We went through 3 supervisors in 3 months) were never around on weekends, which were the only times I worked due to being a high school student. Also, my coworkers were not nice and never wanted to be there. One resident even pointed out that she liked me because I actually smiled when I delivered her food, unlike the other servers. Also, I had to work for pretty much the entire weekends straight because we were so understaffed.

review_title: Awesome organization-dedicated to serving its residents and employees!
pros: PHS is truly a ministry dedicated to its mission of honoring God by enriching the lives and touching the hearts of older adults. Employees are valued and empowered to make a difference in the lives of older adults! I’ve worked in the LTC industry for 30+ years and have the wisdom to appreciate that PHS is one of the best. If you are dedicated to service excellence, join our team!
cons: No cons! Policies and expectations of all employees are clearly communicated.

job_title: Home Health Aide in Roseville, MN
pros: The jobs itself was very satisfying.
cons: The culture of the company was very christian focused, and this was mixed in with most of our meetings and other company gatherings, which felt unprofessional to me. To others this might be ideal but to me it felt unprofessional. Also, there was a little less patient variety and diversity than other home health agencies I have worked with, since many of the patients live in Presbyterian Homes locations, which are more expensive to live at.

pros: Fair pay, kind people, internal growth
cons: You pray daily, can't be yourself "church" behavior all day. Hard to break into clicks. Promotions go to people in the company the longest it's not dependent if you have experience outside of their company and higher education.

review_title: An amazing opportunity to serve the elderly.
pros: The work-environment is laid-back for the most part. The training consists of a few online workshops (to become a server), followed by a few shifts of working under a fellow server. The work-life balance is great because there is no working from home required and the job is enjoyable for the most part.
cons: Occasionally have to deal with frustrated residents or clean up bodily messes in the dining room.

review_title: Decent job if you’re in school, part time work available.
pros: Being a server here is great for experience as a first job, it has a safe work environment & you get to interact and build relationships with residents.
cons: I found it difficult to ask days off, or rather, the days I asked off were ignored completely. Not flexible with weekly hours.

review_title: Regional Management turns a blind eye
pros: Wonderful residents and front line staff.
cons: Mission and vision in Wisconsin does not reflect the company's mission and vision.  The regional head nurse is backstabbing and cruel. Turnover is off the charts. False accusations are made and regional management is more of a click then a support.  DO NOT share your concerns. You will be singled out and bullied until you quit.

pros: Good coworkers. Nice residents. A place to learn the ropes.
cons: The pay was poor. They didn't have as high productivity expectations as for profit organizations, but still high. Expectation of point of service documentation. Management was disorganized and had favorites. They try to play off one of their benefits as being a non-profit, Christian organization with strong values but they are trying to compete with Aegis which has terrible ethics.

pros: Great benefits, PTO, nice co-workers, friendly residences, excellent compensation
cons: Low Census means hours are cut DAILY, poor management at Gracepointe Crossing, HR doesn't reply to emails or effectively communicate.

pros: Pres Homes has a wonderful culture of service and caring for residents. While a Christian-based company, PHS certainly makes all (residents and staff) feel welcome. Good benefits. Lots of opportunities to learn and grow. Retention is important to the company. Great scholarship opportunities.
cons: Workload at times can be intense, pay not stellar but competitive.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Spring Park, MN
pros: It's all about the residents. They are why we come to work.
cons: Heavy and unequal workload, often work short staffed, no support from management. No accountability for sloppy work. Significant pay scale differences between CC and AL. More responsibility in AL and much LOWER salary.

pros: Amazing atmosphere! Pres homes loves their employees like they love their residents. Never have I worked somewhere that I actually felt this valued.  Great for networking and meeting other with similar values.
cons: Can't think of anything I could complain about.

pros: Great people. Ethical treatment and billing. Low productivity requirements for therapists leading to higher quality care.
cons: Lower than average pay. Benefits are average. Frequent low census.

review_title: It was alright but its dead-end
job_title: Manager in Oak Park Heights, MN
pros: Great hours, don't have to do anything,
cons: You get bored after a couple months, management is a joke all over there, and the whole place is hiring anybody even people who literally are horrible people

review_title: Great first time job. Easy and great experience
pros: Easy job, good pay, flexible schedule, nice coworkers, great environment, convenient location, residents are really nice, friendly service, great benefits
cons: None what so ever. Enjoy every second of work. I'm just writing stuff now because they have a twenty word minimum

pros: If you are a Christian and want religion permeating your job then, PHS may be for you.
cons: Greater care needs to be given to customer service experience.  Staff education needs improvement.

review_title: Need to do the work of 4 people
job_title: Care Center Billing Specialist in Roseville, MN
pros: Able to begin your day and end your day when you wanted to, with in reason, as long as your got your 40 hours in. I.E. could leave early on Fridays.
cons: Very demanding. Nothing is consistent across different billers; Life/work balance.

review_title: Johanna Shores is a great place to work.
pros: They are very organized and management is very nice! I love working there and would recommend it to everyone.
cons: I don't have any cons at this time.

pros: Worked with great people, very rewarding, developed relationships with residents and lasting friendships with co-workers, positive work environment, everyone here truly cares about our residents happiness, my boss was also very flexible with scheduling me.
cons: I didn't get paid very much

job_title: Home Care Services Coordinator in Roseville, MN
pros: Really nice staff, really motivated to promote full time hourly employees get 2 raises a year
cons: Wage not the high starting hm hm hm hm hm hm hm hm hm hm hm. Hm hm. Hm. Hmm hm

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Roseville, MN
pros: Flexible, caring, understanding, supportive, provide education opportunities, great benefits, advancement in company available, great culture to be a part of.
cons: Pay could be higher, the work load for some CNAs could be less, scheduling does have some issues.

job_title: Lead/Supervisor Nutrition and Culinary Services in Plymouth, MN
pros: The residents and guests are the best
cons: A lot of miscommunications, upper management don’t really care when the department is short, a lot of OT, a lot of turnovers. Wish pay was better

pros: Residents are a pleasure to work for. many staff are helpful.
cons: Too many managers. Micromanagement. Actual workplace operation Inconsistent with policies. No positive feedback for employees,  just negative.

job_title: Regional Engineer and Late An Environmental Services Manager in Roseville, MN
pros: Due to its religious base it tends to be more conservative which I liked.
cons: Under the skin it was not all it was made out to be

pros:
- Friendly and supportive work environment
- Good benefits
- Opportunities for career advancement
- The people here care. They care about their employees and those they serve.
cons: I honestly cannot think of any.

pros: The Residents that live in the facilities.
cons: Christianity used as a tool to control the staff.  The higher position you have the more qualified you are to lead prayer...which happens multiple times daily.  Despite being 'good christians' they put the almighty dollar above their employees.  Wages are low for all except CEO and multiple vice presidents.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Culture  workers , time off  communication,  good work ethics
cons: Not enough staff,  over load over work, work as many roles in a shift

job_title: Resident Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Very good place to work. Good benefits, tuition reimbursement and scholarships for student, opportunities to grow within the company.
cons: Pay could be better otherwise good company to work at.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Prior Lake, MN
pros: Great employer,  awesome residence, clean facility
cons: High turn over of RA's or just showing up late/not at all

pros: Great benefits, great people, overall great place to work
cons: Growing company, a lot to manage

pros: Family Friendly Hours. Quality of Life.
cons: Inconsistant HR policies. To many mid level managment gets in the way of decision making.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Waukesha, WI
pros: Great training and willing to help  out in any way
cons: Hard to take any lunch

review_title: Underpaid and worked like a horse
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Stillwater, MN
pros: The residents. The residents.
cons: The patient to aid ratio is unsafe and too much. Not paid enough for the work load. If you want to be treated like slave it’s the job for you!

pros: At least It's a job!
cons: Never have enough help working there in any department.

pros: team work, family oreniented, desire to learn, continue education and provide care
cons: occasion rollovers, ocassion rollovers, ocassion rollovers, occassion rollovers and occassion rollovers

pros: The people are amazing. An empowering environment and a fun workplace.
cons: I have not had any negative experiences while working here.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Arden Hills, MN
pros: They have a wonderful nursing reimbursement program.
cons: Coming to work in the mornings you are always short staffed. The work is very busy.

pros: Excellent management, good work/life balance, solid culture and values
cons: Raises are cost-of-living only and not based on performance

job_title: Registered Nurse in Oak Park Heights, MN
pros: Scholarships, Loan pay back, upward movement
cons: poor communication, poor benefits, high deductible 18000 family and 6000 individual, no breaks

review_title: Awesome place to work as a student!
pros: Flexible, great pay, short shifts and fun coworkers.
cons: Not many hours and always hot!

pros: Employees are great and the residents are fantastic to work with.
cons: nothing. I've never had an issue

job_title: HHA/Resident Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: 401 K, a ton of job openings.
cons: Health Benifits, NO STAFF WORKING SHORT STAFFED ALL THE TIME!

pros: Very fulfilling environment, nice staff to work with.
cons: Staff is not held to the same expectations.

job_title: Building Engineer II in Plymouth, MN
pros: Cheap lunches, great customers, and low key.
cons: Big time back stabbing in management. No one supports you and what you do/say. If they don't like you, you'll be looking for a new job.

job_title: RN, Bsn in Spring Park, MN
pros: Helpful and friendly environment! Great management at LMS site!
cons: A bit far from the cities!

job_title: Resident Assistant in New Richmond, WI
pros: Very kind management, clean, good care
cons: Nothing that I would consider a con

pros: Great environment. Fun getting to know residents. Great hours.
cons: constantly needing to hire new employees.

review_title: Overall a Good Place to Work at
job_title: Server in Oak Park Heights, Washington, MN

cons: slow at times at night

pros: The job was consistent. Not very difficult.
cons: Sometimes management was very unorganized.

pros: Really nice and understanding staff
cons: wish to have more hourly rates
